Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies



BC Systems is committed to maintaining a safe work environment. The Plant Engineer for the BC Systems BC Salinas site ensures that safe practices are followed in operations involving hazardous materials. This site has established emergency procedures for ammonia releases. The BC Systems BC Salinas emergency personnel will coordinate with the local Fire Department to ensure rapid and appropriate response to hazardous material emergencies, which include response to emergencies related to the ammonia refrigeration system covered by this CalARP/PSM Program. The site has written evacuation, reporting, and response procedures in place to protect BC Systems employees, the public, and the environment in the event of an ammonia release.



Stationary Source and Regulated Substances



The BC Systems facility covered by this RMP is to be located at 1341 Merrill Street in Salinas, California. The facility receives lettuce and other produce to be processed, packaged for consumer use in various salad mixes, set for short-term storage, and transported and distributed from this site. The regulated substance is anhydrous ammonia. Three portable units use ammonia refrigeration in the product cooling process. The Cooler system uses ammonia refrigeration to maintain product at various temperatures. Anhydrous ammonia is a regulated substance under CalARP's Title 19 Chapter 4.5 Article 8 Section 2770.5.

 



Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps



Prevention of accidental ammonia releases at BC Systems is accomplished through sound industry practice in the original system design and construction, the specification and review of system modifications prior to their occurrence, and the regular operation, maintenance and monitoring of the system. This includes:

?    Compliance with industry standards and codes in effect at the time of initial construction of the system, as well as in the

event of system modifications through a management of change process.

?    Performance of a Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) at least once every five years using accurate process safety information.

?    Implementation of operating, maintenance and monitoring procedures.

?    Training of system operations and maintenance personnel, as well as ongoing training of the onsite

?    Chemical Response Team.

?    Performance of preventive and corrective maintenance according to system component manufacturer recommendations and pursuant to hot work permit program requirements to ensure mechanical integrity.

?    Application of established auditing, inspection, and pre-start-up review protocols.

?    Use of qualified contractors for work on the system.



CalARP's Risk Management Prevention Program 3, Title 19 Chapter 4.5 Article 6 and CalOSHA's Process Safety Management Standard Title 8 Section 5189 outline the facilities accidental release prevention program.  Included are 13 Chemical Specific Prevention steps implemented by BC Systems and are summarized below.



?    Employee Participation - Employees are given shared responsibility with management in the continued evolution of the program.

?    Process Safety Information - Chemical, equipment, and system information has been compiled to ensure the safe design and operation.

?    Process Hazard Analysis - What-if Checklist completed to identify potential hazards and minimize their impact.

?    Operating Procedures - Standard Operating Procedures developed to ensure the safe operation of the process.

?    Training - Training program established and operators trained to ensure the safe operation of the process.

?    Contractors - Contractor program established to ensure only qualified and trained contractor work on or near the process.

?    Pre-Startup Safety Review - Procedures and check lists developed to ensure all safety requirements are completed before startup of new or modified process.

?    Mechanical Integrity - Program developed to ensure equipme

nt and systems installed per design specifications and maintained per manufacturer recommendations and good engineering practices.

?    Hot Work Permit - Permit program established to prevent the potential of fire/explosion resulting from hot work near hazardous chemicals.

?    Management of Change - Procedures established to manage process changes to ensure the integrity of the PSM program is maintained.

?    Incident Investigations - Procedures established to investigate releases that resulted in or could have resulted in a catastrophic release of a hazardous chemical and to prevent recurrence.

?    Compliance Audits - Procedures established to periodically review program implementation and to correct as necessary.

?    Trade Secrets - Policy implemented to provide all necessary information regardless of trade secrets to ensure employee safety.



Five Year Accident History



There is no 5-Year Accident History



Emergency Response Program



BC Systems is included in the written community emergency response plan.  The facility has its own emergency action plan.  The emergency action plan includes procedures for informing the public and local response agencies of a chemical release.  The emergency action plan also includes information on emergency health care.



BC Systems does not respond to emergencies.  BC Systems coordinates its Emergency Action Plan with the Salinas Fire Department. 



Planned Changes to Improve Safety



BC Systems has recently performed a Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) per their Process Safety Management and Risk Management programs.  Areas for improvement during the PHA were identified and corrective actions recommended.  All recommendations are promptly addressed.
